context: <b5_0>Muslim scientists<b5_0/> contributed to advances in the sciences. They placed far greater emphasis on experiment than had the Greeks. This led to <b6_0>an early scientific method<b6_0/> being developed in the Muslim world, where progress in methodology was made, beginning with the experiments of <b7_0>Ibn al-Haytham<b7_0/> (Alhazen) on <a0_0>optics<a0_0/> from circa 1000, in his <a1_0><b8_0>Book of Optics<b8_0/><a1_0/>. The most important development of the scientific method was the use of experiments to distinguish between competing scientific theories set within a generally empirical orientation, which began among Muslim scientists. <a2_0>Ibn al-Haytham<a2_0/> is also regarded as the father of optics, especially for his empirical proof of the intromission theory of light. Some have also described Ibn al-Haytham as the "first scientist." <a3_0>al-Khwarzimi<a3_0/>'s invented the log base systems that are being used today, he also contributed theorems in trigonometry as well as limits. Recent studies show that it is very likely that the <a4_0>Medieval Muslim artists<a4_0/> were aware of advanced decagonal <b9_0>quasicrystal geometry<b9_0/> (discovered half a millennium later in the 1970s and 1980s in the West) and used it in intricate decorative tilework in the architecture.
